This Sunday at 11:00 a.m. in our worship service for the Fifth Sunday in Lent, the scripture lessons remind us that God is in the business of doing new things. The prophet Isaiah proclaims God‚Äôs plan to do a new thing bringing life in places that are destitute and dry. The apostle Paul writes about leaving behind his old ways and the status he once valued for the immeasurable good of knowing and belonging to Jesus. In his gospel, John reminds us that the path from the old to the new involves Jesus‚Äôs death.
Join us for Choral Vespers tomorrow evening at 7:00 p.m. It's a service with prayer and scripture reading with Baroque and Renaissance music led by the Vespers Ensemble.
Join us online today at 12-noon for a brief Midweek service of prayer and scripture reading:
Artist Margaret Parker created the Stations of Cross paintings now on display in the Chapel. They depict Christ's Journey to the Cross with contemporary figures rendered in muted browns.

Coming to the Chapel next Monday and Tuesday: The labyrinth is a forty-foot circle containing a winding path. Walking it prayerfully or as a meditation is an ancient spiritual tradition in many faiths. Details: https://buff.ly/3qKHX4i .

Enjoy this rebroadcast of a recent carillon recital.

Our concert this Sunday offers an opportunity to both remember and rejoice inside the majestic Duke Chapel with music that is at turns solemn and celebratory. All three Chapel choirs will perform with music by Faur√©, Mendelssohn, and Langlais‚Äîplus the world premiere of two compositions!
Duke University Chapel's Video
How do professors relate their faith and their intellectual work? Find out in a series of Faith and Learning lunchtime discussions.

Chapel Dean Luke Powery draws a lesson from a master gardener‚ÄîGod‚Äîin his latest Duke Chronicle column: You are made of matter‚Äîthe dust of the earth‚Äîand for that reason alone your life matters.

I can hear God speaking as a Great Gardener to us: 'Give it one more year. I‚Äôm not giving up on you. Let‚Äôs try one more phone call. Let‚Äôs try one more intervention. Let‚Äôs try one more therapy session. Let‚Äôs try one more gym workout. Let‚Äôs try one more surgery. Let‚Äôs try one more attempt at reconciliation and healing. Let‚Äôs try one more attempt at peace talks. You matter.'‚Äù

Duke senior Joy Reeves will give the sermon this Sunday in our 11:00 a.m. worship service. Selected as this year's Student Preacher, Reeves will deliver a sermon titled Little Ponds about how her experience of finding community during the pandemic connects with a scripture passage about reconciliation.

Students have an opportunity to hear from professors about how they connect the work of their minds with the work of their hearts and spirits. The Chapel is organizing the conversations in partnership with the Duke Academic Guides program. Next Tuesday, March 29, at 12-noon, at the tent between Few and Craven Quads, hear from Chapel Dean Luke Powery and Sanford School of Public Policy Professor Pope McCorkle.

As you plan your visit to Duke Chapel, please note that we are closed all day this Saturday, March 26, to allow for weddings. We are otherwise open daily from 10:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. Come visit to marvel at the architecture, say a prayer, or just sit quietly!

This Sunday in our 11:00 a.m. worship service, the Duke Chapel Choir will be joined by the ensemble Magnificat to lead the music. Chapel Dean Luke Powery will preach a sermon titled Mattering, and we will hear from our Mission of the Month, Farmer Foodshare. With a Rose Procession, we will remember Donna Scott, a student at Duke Divinity School, who died recently after a battle with cancer.

After performing last night, the British vocal ensemble Magnificat continues their residency at Duke by joining the Vespers Ensemble to lead the music in Choral Vespers today at 7:00 p.m. in Duke Chapel. The service features William Byrd's double-choir Great Service alongside music by Orlando Gibbons, Robert Parsons, and Thomas Tomkins.

With March Madness approaching, Chapel Dean Luke Powery writes in the Duke Chronicle about parallels between sports and the spiritual life. He describes four commonalities: being part of team or community, having a discipline of practice, navigating wins and losses/up and downs, and seeking faithfulness and persistence rather than perfection.

Rich with music spanning from the Renaissance to the present, our Choral Evensong worship service this Sunday at 4:00 p.m. features sung prayers, psalms, canticles, and organ music. Distinct from the noisy world around us, this service offers a place for quiet contemplation.

The Chapel's Dr. Philip Cave will be a guest on WCPE TheClassicalStation's Preview this Sunday at 7:00 p.m. He will discuss the music of Josquin des Prez and the upcoming performances by the British early music ensemble Magnificat.

This Sunday in our 11:00 a.m. worship service for the Second Sunday of Lent, we will welcome new members into The Congregation at Duke University Chapel. Chapel Assistant Dean Bruce Puckett will preach and a vocal ensemble will sing Psalm settings by Franz Schubert and Benedetto Marcello.

On Saturday, thirteen graduate students gathered at the Respite in the Round farm for an interfaith day retreat on Sacred Earth: Land as Spiritual Practice. The students, who came from a variety of religious backgrounds and worldviews, spent the day in reflection about what it means to understand land as a space for spiritual, relational, and ecological renewal. They received a tour from K Cox and Kisha Jeffries, the stewards of Respite. They also spent time exploring, reflecting, resting on their own.

A review by CVNC.org of the recent Evensong Singers's concert Poetry in Music said: The choir was full-voiced and filled the chapel with glorious sounds. Soloists who sang from the choir were each superb with pleasing vocal timbre.

Light our way, O God, that we may see the way you are leading; guide us in the ways we are to go, the words we are to speak, and the actions we are to take. Move us to boldly follow your call. Make us energetic disciples, who willingly pick up a cross to follow you. And in the midst of all our efforts, remind us of your presence with us. ‚Äî Rev. Dr. Carol Gregg, pastor of The Congregation at Duke University Chapel in the Prayers of the People on Sunday

This Sunday in our 11:00 a.m. worship service, we will observe the First Sunday in Lent. The Chapel observes Lent in our worship services by adapting our practices for the season. In addition to removing the ‚ÄúAlleluias and flowers from our services, we also use a common Lenten confession, adaptations to our prayers of the people, and a Lenten affirmation of faith.

This Lent join us in reading Tattoos on the Heart: The Power of Boundless Compassion by Fr. Gregory Boyle. In it, with wit and tenderness, Fr. Boyle tells the stories and lessons he has learned from creating Homeboy Industries, a nonprofit in Los Angeles that offers former gang members opportunities for work, healing, and belonging.

In the Duke Chronicle this week, Chapel Dean Luke Powery writes about the connection between the ashes caused by the fires of war, like the one in Ukraine, and the ashes administered on the foreheads of people attending Ash Wednesday services. Read the article: https://buff.ly/3CdDETD

Writing about the recent Complicated Truths public conversation and Reliquary of Complicated Truths exhibition at the Chapel, the Duke Chronicle quotes artist Lanecia Rouse Tinsley about the power of hope. Hope lets us see the night stars amidst the dark sky,‚Äù she says.

Coming March 24: Our Jazz Vespers service blends the form of the traditional evening vespers service with the musical improvisation of jazz. With themes of lament and hope, the service combines poetry, ritual, blessings, and music. It is led musically by the John Brown Big Band, a professional jazz ensemble under the direction of John V. Brown, vice provost for .

With so much pain in the world‚Äîpublic and private‚Äîan artist and a theologian take up the topic of the Complicated Truths of life in a public conversation this Thursday at  5:30 p.m. in Duke Chapel. Duke Divinity School Professor Kate Bowler and Lanecia Rouse Tinsely LAR Art Studio will reflect on Bowler's book No Cure for Being Human and Tinsely's new exhibition Reliquary of Complicated Truths.

A group of students and others recently completed the Durham Pilgrimage of Pain and Hope with DurhamCares. The weekend retreat leads participants through historic sites in Durham to better understand how the biblical story intersects with the history of Durham and the lives of those on pilgrimage.

Duke Hindu Students Association will host an online celebration of Makar Sankranti this Friday from 6:00 to 6:30 p.m. Makar Sankranti is a festival that aligns with the solar calendar, and marks the beginning of a new season which brings with it crops and harvest. This festival dedicated to Surya, the Hindu god of sun, is also known as Uttarayan, Maghi, Pongal, Boghi Panduga, and other names across different regions. Join the celebration via Zoom at https://buff.ly/3FiIMph .

Alongside the NC Department of Health and Human Services, Reality Ministries and the Durham Co-op Market, the Chapel teamed up to give away 400 hundred approved N95 masks this week. That makes over 640 masks total that we've helped distribute to neighbors in need over the past two weeks, including to partner organizations, people experiencing homelessness, vulnerable neighbors, and small businesses in the West End.

In approaching the ten-year anniversary of the killing of teenager Trayvon Martin, Chapel Dean Luke Powery says in the Duke Chronicle that he keeps a reminder of Martin‚Äîa bag of Skittle and a can of Arizona Ice Tea‚Äîon his desk right next to a reminder of Jesus's last meal before his death‚Äîa communion plate and cup. He says these items call him to remember people who are suffering. They also remind him to work for healing‚Äîre-membering‚Äîin the world.

The acclaimed British vocal ensemble Magnificat will give two concerts at Duke University, March 16 and 18, featuring early music composers whose work continues to resonate and inspire. In addition to the concerts, the ensemble will sing in Duke Chapel worship services and offer workshops as an ensemble-in-residence March 13‚Äì20. There is no cost to attend the two concerts but free tickets from the Duke Box Office are required for admittance.

Join us for Choral Evensong this Sunday at 4:00 p.m. The service will include Hubert. H. Parry‚Äôs anthem Blest pair of sirens, which was commissioned in celebration of Queen Victoria‚Äôs Golden Jubilee in 1887. The text comes from John Milton‚Äôs ode, At a solemn music, which describes the rapturous effect of sacred music and tuning one‚Äôs heart toward the divine. Parry‚Äôs music embodies a distinctly English synthesis of the great German Romantic composers Brahms and Wagner.

An interactive visual art exhibition at Duke Chapel invites viewers to consider complicated truths in life for which there are no easy solutions. This weekend in our 11:00 a.m. Sunday morning worship service, Chapel Dean Luke Powery will preach a sermon titled Calling based on God's calling of the prophet Jeremiah. The Chapel Choir will lead the congregation in singing The Hope That Calls Us, an original hymn by Chapel Music Director Zebulon Highben composed in 2020 to celebrate the twentieth anniversary of Dean Powery's ordination.

An online seminar The Value of Home: Stewardship for Affordable Housing on February 26 will present ways to address homelessness and affordable housing. The leader of the seminar will be Terry Allebaugh, an adjunct instructor at Sanford School of Public Policy, who has over thirty years of experience as a local, state, and national leader on policy and practice around ending homelessness.

Students: Here's an opportunity to live on West Campus next year and be part of a community that seeks to grow together in knowledge and faith. Eruditio et Religio is an interfaith living-learning community in Keohane 4B for learning about diverse religious traditions through a multitude of frameworks, reading both scholarly texts and children's stories, talking with professors and spiritual leaders, visiting Duke religious groups and Durham spiritual communities. Kudos to the Duke Chapel Choir for being among the semi-finalists for a national award for virtual performance. Last year, the choir adapted to the pandemic by making recordings from their homes that were mixed together and then streamed as part of Chapel worship services. It was a way for the group to keep singing and offering the beauty and hope of sacred music.

A special service of Choral Vespers tomorrow (Thursday) at 7:00 p.m. celebrates the Feast of the Epiphany with music from German, Spanish, and English composers. In particular, the canticle for the service uses the text from the Magnificat interspersed with German Christmas carols, set to music by the Baroque-era, German composer Samuel Scheidt.
